text_summary: Acute epidural hematoma identified as a biconvex hyperdense extra-axial collection in the temporal region, causing midline shift. This is a neurosurgical emergency requiring immediate evacuation.
clinical_significance: Life-threatening extra-axial hemorrhage typically associated with temporal bone fracture and middle meningeal artery rupture.
differential_diagnosis: Subdural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, dural metastasis
recommended_followup: Emergent neurosurgical consultation, repeat CT head if clinical deterioration

text_summary: Acute subdural hematoma presenting as a crescent-shaped hyperdense collection along the cerebral convexity with 8mm midline shift and early uncal herniation.
clinical_significance: High-mortality extra-axial hemorrhage from bridging vein rupture, common in elderly and anticoagulated patients.
differential_diagnosis: Epidural hematoma, subdural hygroma, chronic subdural hematoma
recommended_followup: Emergent neurosurgery evaluation for craniotomy vs burr hole drainage

text_summary: Diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage with blood in the basal cisterns and sylvian fissures bilaterally, consistent with aneurysmal rupture. Fisher grade 3.
clinical_significance: Aneurysmal SAH carries high morbidity from vasospasm and rebleeding. Requires urgent CTA to identify the culprit aneurysm.
differential_diagnosis: Traumatic SAH, perimesencephalic hemorrhage, cortical vein thrombosis
recommended_followup: CT angiography head, neurosurgery/neurointerventional consultation

text_summary: Solid pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe measuring 8mm in maximum diameter. No calcification or fat attenuation. Smooth margins.
clinical_significance: Solid nodule 6-8mm in a high-risk patient warrants follow-up CT at 6-12 months per Lung-RADS 3 criteria.
differential_diagnosis: Primary lung malignancy, metastasis, granuloma, hamartoma
recommended_followup: CT chest low-dose follow-up at 6 months

text_summary: Large solid pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe measuring 22mm. Spiculated margins with adjacent pleural retraction. Highly suspicious for primary lung malignancy.
clinical_significance: Spiculated solid nodule greater than 15mm is highly suspicious for malignancy (Lung-RADS 4B). Tissue sampling required.
differential_diagnosis: Primary non-small cell lung cancer, carcinoid tumor, metastasis, organizing pneumonia
recommended_followup: PET/CT, tissue biopsy (CT-guided or bronchoscopic), multidisciplinary oncology review

text_summary: Ground-glass nodule in the right middle lobe measuring 12mm, persistent on follow-up imaging over 6 months. No solid component identified.
clinical_significance: Persistent pure ground-glass nodule greater than 10mm may represent adenocarcinoma in situ or minimally invasive adenocarcinoma.
differential_diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma in situ, minimally invasive adenocarcinoma, atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, focal inflammation
recommended_followup: Short-interval CT follow-up at 3 months, consider PET/CT or biopsy if growing

text_summary: Tension pneumothorax on the left side with complete lung collapse, mediastinal shift to the right, and flattening of the left hemidiaphragm. Deep sulcus sign present.
clinical_significance: Life-threatening condition requiring immediate needle decompression followed by chest tube insertion.
differential_diagnosis: Large simple pneumothorax, hemothorax with contralateral shift
recommended_followup: Emergent needle decompression, chest tube placement, repeat CXR post-intervention

text_summary: Small simple pneumothorax at the right apex measuring approximately 1.5cm from the chest wall. No mediastinal shift. Lung parenchyma otherwise normal.
clinical_significance: Small primary spontaneous pneumothorax may be managed conservatively with observation in stable patients.
differential_diagnosis: Skin fold artifact, bulla
recommended_followup: Serial CXR in 6 hours, consider CT if uncertain, outpatient follow-up if stable

text_summary: Moderate left-sided pleural effusion with meniscus sign and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lower lobe. No loculations identified.
clinical_significance: Moderate pleural effusion requires clinical correlation. Differential includes transudative (CHF, cirrhosis) and exudative (infection, malignancy) causes.
differential_diagnosis: Congestive heart failure, parapneumonic effusion, malignant effusion, empyema
recommended_followup: Thoracentesis for fluid analysis if new or unexplained, echocardiogram if CHF suspected

text_summary: Lobar pneumonia involving the right lower lobe with dense consolidation, air bronchograms, and associated small parapneumonic effusion.
clinical_significance: Lobar consolidation with air bronchograms is characteristic of bacterial pneumonia. Parapneumonic effusion should be monitored for empyema.
differential_diagnosis: Bacterial pneumonia, organizing pneumonia, lymphoma, bronchoalveolar carcinoma
recommended_followup: Sputum culture, blood cultures, follow-up CXR in 6-8 weeks to confirm resolution

text_summary: Cardiomegaly with a cardiothoracic ratio of 0.62. Bilateral pulmonary vascular congestion and small bilateral pleural effusions suggest congestive heart failure.
clinical_significance: Cardiothoracic ratio greater than 0.5 indicates cardiomegaly. Combined with pulmonary congestion and effusions, this suggests decompensated heart failure.
differential_diagnosis: Dilated cardiomyopathy, pericardial effusion, valvular heart disease
recommended_followup: Echocardiogram, BNP levels, cardiology consultation

text_summary: Acute displaced fracture of the right 7th and 8th ribs laterally with a small associated hemothorax. No flail segment identified.
clinical_significance: Multiple rib fractures increase risk for pulmonary contusion, hemothorax, and pneumothorax. Pain management is critical to prevent atelectasis.
differential_diagnosis: Pathologic fracture, stress fracture, costal cartilage injury
recommended_followup: Pain management, incentive spirometry, repeat CXR if worsening symptoms, trauma surgery if flail chest develops

text_summary: Acute pulmonary embolism with filling defects in the right main pulmonary artery and bilateral segmental branches. RV/LV ratio of 1.3 indicating right heart strain.
clinical_significance: Saddle or central PE with right heart strain is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent anticoagulation or thrombolysis.
differential_diagnosis: Chronic thromboembolic disease, in-situ thrombosis, tumor embolus, air embolism
recommended_followup: Systemic anticoagulation, consider catheter-directed therapy or systemic thrombolysis, echocardiogram, lower extremity duplex ultrasound

text_summary: Stanford type A aortic dissection with an intimal flap extending from the ascending aorta through the arch into the descending thoracic aorta. True lumen compression noted.
clinical_significance: Type A aortic dissection is a surgical emergency with high mortality if untreated. Immediate cardiothoracic surgery consultation required.
differential_diagnosis: Intramural hematoma, penetrating aortic ulcer, aortic aneurysm with mural thrombus
recommended_followup: Emergent cardiothoracic surgery consultation for open repair, blood pressure control, serial imaging post-repair

text_summary: Active demyelinating lesion in the periventricular white matter with ring enhancement on post-gadolinium T1 and hyperintense FLAIR signal. Measures 15mm.
clinical_significance: Enhancing periventricular lesion in the appropriate clinical context is consistent with active multiple sclerosis relapse per McDonald criteria.
differential_diagnosis: Tumefactive MS, CNS lymphoma, brain abscess, neuromyelitis optica
recommended_followup: Neurology consultation, CSF analysis if first presentation, consider IV methylprednisolone for acute relapse

text_summary: Stable periventricular and juxtacortical white matter lesions consistent with chronic demyelination. No new enhancing lesions identified. Previously documented MS.
clinical_significance: Stable chronic MS lesion burden without new activity suggests adequate disease control on current therapy.
differential_diagnosis: Small vessel ischemic disease, migraine-related white matter changes, vasculitis
recommended_followup: Continue current disease-modifying therapy, routine MRI surveillance in 6-12 months per McDonald criteria

text_summary: Multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions in the cerebral hemispheres at the gray-white junction, largest measuring 25mm. Surrounding vasogenic edema and mass effect.
clinical_significance: Multiple ring-enhancing lesions at the gray-white junction are highly suspicious for cerebral metastases. Primary tumor search indicated.
differential_diagnosis: Brain abscess, primary CNS lymphoma, tumefactive demyelination, toxoplasmosis
recommended_followup: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for primary tumor workup, neurosurgery/radiation oncology consultation, consider stereotactic biopsy

text_summary: Dense consolidation in the right middle and lower lobes with air bronchograms consistent with community-acquired pneumonia. No cavitation or abscess formation.
clinical_significance: Multilobar pneumonia increases severity and may warrant hospital admission per CURB-65 or PSI scoring.
differential_diagnosis: Aspiration pneumonia, organizing pneumonia, pulmonary hemorrhage
recommended_followup: Empiric antibiotics per guidelines, follow-up CXR in 6-8 weeks to ensure resolution

text_summary: Subsegmental atelectasis at the left lung base with volume loss and elevated left hemidiaphragm. Linear opacities consistent with discoid atelectasis.
clinical_significance: Subsegmental atelectasis is a common post-operative or incidental finding. Usually resolves with incentive spirometry and ambulation.
differential_diagnosis: Early pneumonia, pulmonary infarct, mucus plugging
recommended_followup: Incentive spirometry, ambulation, follow-up CXR only if symptomatic

text_summary: Bilateral pulmonary edema with bilateral perihilar ground-glass opacities, interlobular septal thickening (Kerley B lines), and bilateral pleural effusions. Consistent with cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
clinical_significance: Acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema indicates decompensated heart failure requiring urgent diuresis and cardiac evaluation.
differential_diagnosis: ARDS, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, diffuse pneumonia, fluid overload
recommended_followup: Echocardiogram, BNP levels, diuretic therapy, cardiology consultation

text_summary: Well-circumscribed hypervascular hepatic lesion with peripheral nodular enhancement and centripetal fill-in on delayed phases, classic for hepatic hemangioma. Measures 4.2cm.
clinical_significance: Classic hemangioma enhancement pattern is highly specific. Benign lesion requiring no treatment unless symptomatic or very large.
differential_diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma, hypervascular metastasis, focal nodular hyperplasia
recommended_followup: No follow-up needed if classic appearance. MRI with hepatobiliary contrast if atypical features.

text_summary: Simple cortical cyst in the left kidney measuring 3.5cm with water attenuation, thin imperceptible wall, and no enhancement. Bosniak category I.
clinical_significance: Simple renal cysts are extremely common benign findings requiring no treatment or follow-up.
differential_diagnosis: Complicated cyst, cystic renal cell carcinoma, calyceal diverticulum
recommended_followup: No follow-up required for Bosniak I cysts

text_summary: Large right upper lobe lung mass measuring 5.8cm with irregular margins, central necrosis, and ipsilateral mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Highly suspicious for primary lung malignancy.
clinical_significance: Large lung mass with mediastinal lymphadenopathy suggests locally advanced non-small cell lung cancer. Staging workup required.
differential_diagnosis: Primary lung cancer (NSCLC), lymphoma, metastasis, lung abscess
recommended_followup: PET/CT staging, tissue biopsy, brain MRI, pulmonary function tests, multidisciplinary tumor board

text_summary: Small solid pulmonary nodule measuring 4mm in the left lower lobe. Smooth borders, no calcification. Incidental finding in low-risk patient.
clinical_significance: Solid nodule less than 6mm in a low-risk patient is classified as Lung-RADS 2, likely benign. No routine follow-up recommended.
differential_diagnosis: Granuloma, intrapulmonary lymph node, small metastasis
recommended_followup: No routine follow-up recommended per Fleischner Society 2017 guidelines for low-risk patients

text_summary: Acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right basal ganglia measuring 3.2 x 2.8cm with surrounding edema and mild mass effect on the right lateral ventricle. No intraventricular extension.
clinical_significance: Hypertensive basal ganglia hemorrhage is the most common cause of spontaneous ICH. Volume and location determine prognosis and surgical candidacy.
differential_diagnosis: Hemorrhagic transformation of infarct, amyloid angiopathy, vascular malformation, hemorrhagic tumor
recommended_followup: ICU admission, blood pressure management, neurosurgery consultation, CTA to exclude underlying lesion, repeat CT in 6 hours
